lg.l: O navis, referent, &c.
Paraphrased and Inscribed to Ir────d.
The Publisher to the READER:

THE following ODE, (being supposed to be by the same Author) having been formerly printed, and received with universal Applause, and being very scarce, I am confident, the Publick will be oblig'd to me for re-printing it.
The INSCRIPTION,
Poor floating Isle, tost on ill Fortune's Waves, Fate to be the Land of S-----s:Delos now deep-rooted stand,.
Ordain'd by
Shall moving
Thou, fixt of old, be now the moving Land?
Altho' the Metaphor be worn and stale
Betwixt a State, and Vessel under Sail;
Let me suppose thee for a Ship a while,
And thus address thee in the Sailor Stile
1O navis, referent in mare te noviFluctus:UNHAPPY Ship, thou art return'd in vain:
New Waves shall drive thee to the Deep again.
Look to thy Self, and be no more the Sport2──────Fortiter occupaPortum: Of giddy Winds, but make some friendly Port.
2Nudum remigio latus. Lost are thy Oars that us'd thy Course to guide,
Like faithful Counsellors on either Side.
3──Malus celeri saucius Africo. Thy Mast, which like some aged Patriot stood
The single Pillar for his Country's Good,
To lead thee, as a Staff directs the Blind,
Behold, it cracks by yon rough Eastern Wind.
4────────────Ac sine funibusVix durare carinaePossint imperiosiusAEquor? Your Cable's burst, and you must quickly feel
The Waves impetuous entring at your Keel.
Thus, Commonwealths receive a foreign Yoke,
When the strong Cords of Union once are broke.
5Non tibi sunt integra lintea. Torn by a sudden Tempest is thy Sail,
Expanded to invite a milder Gale.
As when some Writer in a publick Cause,
His Pen to save a sinking Nation draws,
While all is Calm, his Arguments prevail,
The People's Voice expand his Paper Sail;
'Till Pow'r discharging all her stormy Bags,
Flutters the feeble Pamphlet into Rags.
The Nation scar'd, the Author doom'd to Death,
Who fondly put his Trust in pop'lar Breath.
A larger Sacrifice in Vain you vow; 6Non Dii, quos interum pressa voces malo. There's not a Pow'r above will help you now:
A Nation thus, who oft Heav'ns Call neglects,
In Vain from injur'd Heav'n Relief expects.
7Quamvis Pontica pinus,Sylvae filia nobilis. 'Twill not avail, when thy strong Sides are broke,
That thy Descent is from the British Oak:
Or when your Name and Family you boast,
From Fleets triumphant o'er the Gallick Coast.
Such was Ierne's Claim, as just as thine,
Her Sons descended from the British Line;
Her matchless Sons; whose Valour still remains
On French Records for twenty long Campains;
Yet from an Empress, now a Captive grown,
She sav'd Britannia's Right, and lost her own.
8Nil pictis timidus navita puppibus. In Ships decay'd no Mariner confides,
Lur'd by the gilded Stern, and painted Sides.
Yet, at a Ball, unthinking Fools delight
In the gay Trappings of a Birth-Day Night:
They on the Gold Brocades and Satins rav'd,
And quite forgot their Country was enslav'd.
9Fidit tu, nisi ventisDebes ludibrium, cave:Dear Vessel, still be to thy Steerage just,
Nor, change thy Course with ev'ry sudden Gust:
Like supple Patriots of the modern Sort,
Who turn with ev'ry Gale that blows from Court.
10Nuper sollicitum quae mihi taedium,Nunc desiderium, curàque non levis,Interfusa nitentesVites aequora Cycladas.Weary and Sea-sick when in thee confin'd,
Now, for thy Safety Cares distract my Mind,
As those who long have stood the Storms of State,
Retire, yet still bemoan their Country's Fate.
Beware, and when you hear the Surges roar,
Avoid the Rocks on Britain's angry Shore:
They lye, alas! too easy to be found,
For thee alone they lye the Island round.
